emissions.closest_match_explanation: The ingredient '1.75 cups coconut milk' is directly matched to 'coconut milk' as it is an exact and specific match. This choice aligns with the principle of using the most direct and accurate emission factor available for the ingredient.

The ingredient '3.5 tbsp green curry paste' is directly matched to 'green curry paste' as it is an exact and specific match. This choice aligns with the principle of using the most direct and accurate emission factor available for the ingredient.

The ingredient '1 cup chicken stock' is best matched to 'bouillon, chicken, prepared'. This is because 'chicken stock' is a liquid, ready-to-use product, similar to 'bouillon, chicken, prepared', which implies a ready-to-eat liquid form. This aligns with the principle of matching based on the processing level and common sense, as a concentrated bouillon cube would not be measured in 'cups' for direct use.

The ingredient '1 lb chicken thigh' is best matched to 'chicken, leg, flesh and skin, raw'. This is because chicken thigh is a specific cut of chicken, and 'chicken, leg, flesh and skin, raw' represents a raw, unprocessed form of a similar part of the chicken. This aligns with the principle of choosing the least processed option when no exact match for the specific cut is available, and it is a realistic comparison.
emissions.closest_match_name: chicken, leg, flesh and skin, raw

emissions.closest_match_explanation: The ingredient '2 tbsp palm sugar' is best matched to 'sugar, sucrose, white'. While 'palm sugar' is a specific type of sugar, 'sugar, sucrose, white' is the most appropriate broader category available that represents a refined sugar product. This choice is made because both are forms of sugar and are likely to have similar CO2 emissions compared to other options like 'coconut milk', which is not a sugar.

The ingredient '1.5 tbsp fish sauce' is best matched to 'chili sauce'. While not an exact match, 'chili sauce' is a processed condiment, similar in nature to 'fish sauce' as both are liquid flavorings. 'Soya sauce' is also a processed condiment, but 'chili sauce' has a slightly higher emission factor, and both are viable options, so the one with the higher emission factor is chosen as per the rule for tie-breaking. 'Fish balls, canned' is not a suitable match as it is a solid food product.
